sources: North Dakota Game and Fish Department (NDGF)
South Dakota Game, Fish and Parks (SDGFP)
Kansas Department of Wildlife and Parks (KDWP)
Iowa Department of Natural Resources (Iowa DNR)
notes: Regulations are subject to change. Always verify with official state agencies before fishing.
Some regulations vary by geographic sub-regions and specific water bodies within states.
Emergency orders and proclamations may supersede published regulations.
Special regulations may apply to specific lakes, rivers, and reservoirs.
Always check for posted regulations at individual water bodies.

license_requirements.freshwater: Fishing license required for residents and nonresidents age 16+
license_requirements.notes: Licenses valid April 1 through March 31 of following year. Residents under 16 may fish without license. Four free fishing days annually for ND residents. Paddlefish tag required for paddlefish snaggers. Darkhouse spearfishing requires free registration.

species.bag_limit_notes: Only one over 20 inches allowed in daily bag
species.special_regulations: One-over-20-inches rule protects larger spawning fish

species.bag_limit_notes: Possession limit of 10
species.special_regulations: No size restrictions statewide; check specific water body regulations

species.bag_limit_notes: Possession limit of 10
species.special_regulations: May not be taken with underwater spearfishing gear

species.bag_limit_notes: Possession limit of 40 west of ND Highway 1
species.special_regulations: Higher possession limits west of Highway 1

species.bag_limit_notes: Combined black and white crappie
species.special_regulations: No minimum size statewide

species.bag_limit_notes: Possession limit of 6; all trout species combined
species.special_regulations: Includes rainbow, brown, brook, and other trout species

license_requirements.freshwater: Fishing license required for residents and nonresidents age 18+
license_requirements.notes: Anglers under 18 do not need a license. Various license types available including annual, temporary, and combination licenses.

species.bag_limit_notes: No more than one fish 20 inches or longer may be included in daily limit year-round
species.special_regulations: Some lakes have 18-24 inch protected slot limits. One-over-20-inches rule applies statewide.
species.geographic_restrictions: Statewide with special regulations on select lakes

species.bag_limit_notes: Possession limit of 10
species.special_regulations: No statewide size limit

species.bag_limit_notes: Possession limit of 10
species.special_regulations: No statewide size limit

species.bag_limit_notes: 10 catfish of any species combined; possession limit of 20
species.special_regulations: Combined limit for all catfish species

species.bag_limit_notes: 10 catfish combined species; no more than one flathead over 30 inches
species.special_regulations: Maximum size restriction protects trophy fish

species.bag_limit_notes: Combined black and white crappie
species.special_regulations: Size limits apply to select lakes; check specific water body regulations

species.bag_limit_notes: No statewide minimum size restriction unless posted at specific waters
species.season_closed: Some waters may have seasonal closures
species.special_regulations: Special regulations may apply at specific trout waters; check posted rules

license_requirements.freshwater: Fishing permit required for anyone age 16 or older
license_requirements.notes: Residents under 16 do not need a permit. Nonresident youth under 16 do not need a permit when accompanied by licensed permit holder. Annual, multi-year, 1-day, and 3-day licenses available.

species.bag_limit_notes: Possession limit of 8; one over 22 inches allowed in daily bag
species.special_regulations: One-over-22-inches rule protects trophy fish statewide

species.minimum_size_notes: Varies by water body; 21-inch minimum for trophy bass
species.bag_limit_notes: No more than one black bass 21 inches or longer may be harvested daily from any waters statewide
species.special_regulations: Trophy bass protection: only one over 21 inches per day statewide

species.bag_limit_notes: Black bass aggregate; no more than one over 21 inches statewide
species.special_regulations: Included in black bass aggregate with trophy protection

species.bag_limit_notes: Black bass aggregate; no more than one over 21 inches statewide
species.special_regulations: Included in black bass aggregate with trophy protection

species.bag_limit_notes: Only one fish in the daily bag can be 30 inches or greater statewide
species.special_regulations: Trophy size restriction protects large fish

species.bag_limit_notes: May be included with channel catfish limits
species.special_regulations: Check specific water body regulations

species.bag_limit_notes: No statewide limit; check specific water body regulations
species.special_regulations: Water-specific regulations apply; Flanagan Lake has 10-inch maximum

species.bag_limit_notes: All trout species combined
species.special_regulations: Check specific trout stream and lake regulations

license_requirements.freshwater: Fishing license required for residents age 16-74 and nonresidents age 16+
license_requirements.notes: Residents under 16 and over 74 do not need a license. Various license types available. Individual water bodies may have different regulations than statewide rules.

species.bag_limit_notes: Statewide limit
species.special_regulations: Individual waters may have different limits

species.bag_limit_notes: Statewide limit
species.special_regulations: Individual waters may have different limits

species.bag_limit_notes: Statewide limit
species.special_regulations: Higher minimum size than largemouth bass

species.bag_limit_notes: Statewide limit
species.special_regulations: Lower minimum size than other bass species

species.bag_limit_notes: Only 1 over 30 inches allowed
species.special_regulations: Trophy size protection for fish over 30 inches

species.bag_limit_notes: Statewide limit
species.special_regulations: No size restrictions

species.bag_limit_notes: Lower limit than other catfish species
species.special_regulations: More restrictive limit than channel/blue catfish

species.bag_limit_notes: Combined black and white crappie
species.special_regulations: Individual waters may have different limits

species.bag_limit_notes: Statewide limit
species.season_closed: Some waters may have seasonal restrictions
species.special_regulations: Check specific water body regulations for trout

license_requirements.freshwater: Fishing license required for residents age 16+
license_requirements.notes: Residents under 16 can fish without license but need trout fee to keep their own limit of trout. Licenses required to take, use, possess, or transport fish from inland waters and boundary rivers. Trout fee required to fish for and possess trout.

species.minimum_size_notes: Some lakes have 15-inch minimum; Big Creek Lake has special restrictions
species.bag_limit_notes: Combined daily bag limit; possession limit of 10. Some special lakes have restrictions (e.g., Big Creek Lake: no more than one over 20 inches)
species.special_regulations: Special regulations apply at specific lakes; Big Creek Lake has 15-inch minimum with one-over-20-inches rule

species.bag_limit_notes: Possession limit of 6; applies to all public lakes
species.special_regulations: 15-inch minimum applies to all public lakes

species.bag_limit_notes: Possession limit of 6; black bass aggregate
species.special_regulations: Included in black bass regulations

species.bag_limit_notes: Inland lakes: 8 combined daily, 30 possession. Inland streams and select reservoirs (Coralville, Rathbun, Red Rock, Saylorville): 15 combined daily, 30 possession.
species.special_regulations: Different bag limits for lakes vs streams/reservoirs

species.bag_limit_notes: Included in catfish combined limits (see channel catfish notes)
species.special_regulations: Combined with other catfish species

species.bag_limit_notes: 25-fish daily limit on public waters; no limit on private ponds
species.special_regulations: Generous limits; no size restrictions

species.bag_limit_notes: Combined daily bag limit; possession limit of 10. Trout fee required.
species.special_regulations: Catch and release required on specific posted waters (Hewett Creek, Ensign Creek, McLoud Run, South Pine Creek, Waterloo Creek, Brown Trout in French Creek). Artificial lure only on certain posted streams.
species.geographic_restrictions: Designated trout waters with specific stream regulations

license_requirements.notes: Anglers under 16 and over 64 do not need a permit. Trout permit required to keep trout. Four trout parks (Bennett Spring, Montauk, Roaring River, Maramec Spring) become catch-and-release only November 14, 2025 - February 9, 2026.

species.bag_limit_notes: Combined with sauger; possession limit of 8
species.special_regulations: Combined limit with sauger

species.bag_limit_notes: Combined with walleye; possession limit of 8
species.special_regulations: Combined limit with walleye

species.bag_limit_notes: Statewide minimum 15 inches; limits vary by water body
species.special_regulations: Special regulations apply to major reservoirs and specific water bodies

species.bag_limit_notes: Statewide minimum 15 inches
species.special_regulations: Check specific water body regulations

species.bag_limit_notes: Lower minimum size than other bass species
species.special_regulations: Check specific water body regulations

species.bag_limit_notes: Combined total of channel, blue, and flathead catfish
species.special_regulations: Combined catfish limit

species.bag_limit_notes: Combined total of channel, blue, and flathead catfish
species.special_regulations: Combined catfish limit

species.bag_limit_notes: Combined total of channel, blue, and flathead catfish
species.special_regulations: Combined catfish limit

species.bag_limit_notes: Major reservoirs (Lake of the Ozarks, Table Rock, Truman, Bull Shoals): 15 fish limit. Statewide default: 30 fish combined.
species.special_regulations: Reduced limits on major reservoirs to maintain quality populations

species.bag_limit_notes: All species combined; trout permit required to keep trout
species.season_closed: Four trout parks (Bennett Spring, Montauk, Roaring River, Maramec Spring) catch-and-release only November 14, 2025 - February 9, 2026
species.special_regulations: Catch-and-release periods at trout parks require artificial lures. Trout permit required statewide.
species.geographic_restrictions: Designated trout waters and trout parks

data_compilation: All regulations compiled from official state agency sources and current web resources
Scientific names verified from multiple authoritative sources including U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service
Regulations are effective for 2026 fishing season
Some states operate on calendar year while others use April-March or other license years
regional_characteristics: Northern Plains states feature primarily freshwater fishing opportunities
Walleye is a premier gamefish throughout the region with consistent regulations
Bass species present include largemouth, smallmouth, and spotted bass (varies by state)
Catfish species include channel, blue, and flathead with varying regulations
Trout fishing is available in designated waters, primarily in western portions of the region
Most states protect trophy-sized fish through size restrictions or one-over limits
common_regulatory_patterns: Most states require licenses at age 16+
Walleye minimum sizes range from 14-21 inches across the region
Bass minimum sizes typically 15-18 inches for largemouth, higher for smallmouth
Trophy fish protection common (one-over rules, maximum size limits)
Crappie limits are generous (15-25 fish) with some size minimums
Catfish regulations often include combined species limits
Trout require special permits or stamps in most states
important_reminders: Always check water-specific regulations before fishing
Many states have special regulations for individual lakes and reservoirs
Possession limits typically double the daily bag limits
Emergency orders can change regulations with short notice
Some waters have catch-and-release only regulations
Artificial lure restrictions may apply on certain trout waters
Proper fish measurement techniques are critical for compliance
recommendations: Download state-specific fishing regulation apps for mobile access
Check for updates before each fishing trip
Know how to properly measure fish (total length vs fork length)
Understand the difference between bag limits, possession limits, and size limits
Be aware of seasonal closures, especially for trout
Consider catch-and-release practices for trophy-sized fish
Practice selective harvest to maintain healthy fish populations
